commits.message:
Update error-prone compiler.

This updates the error-prone version to 2.0, which includes full Java 8
support. Error-prone now repackages a copy of javac8, which requires
some classloading changes.

commit_comments.body: Just curious, what formatter did you use for this? I tried to get clang-format to match the project style, but obviously didn't get it quite right.

review_comments.body: You might want to check the key actually starts with '-' before trimming it, otherwise you would get odd results if the compiler mojo ever adds a key without a dash. Also if you iterate over the entry set then you can avoid the extra step to lookup the value, as each entry gives you both the key and value.

commits.message: Groom messages for JDK 6 level prefixes in compiler messages.

issue_comments.body:
IMO seamlessly failing back to an earlier version of the compiler is dangerous, since it sets expectations based on the 1.6-compat version. If someone sets their path wrong, they may get seemingly random new errors in their build without much indication why.

Far better IMO to simply say "you must use 1.6 for this version of the plugin" and then fail. Simple pointer to what they did wrong. Especially since the point of this patch is to clean up error handling because annotation-processor output is handled so poorly in older versions.

My question is how this change interacts with maven-toolchain...or if we're still concerned about the toolchain configuration people supply. With this in-process compiler, you don't have a choice of using an external JDK for compilation.

Maybe not an issue, though. I haven't had a use case for toolchains yet, so I can't say for sure.

I guess that's because you'd have to parse the messages coming from the stderr/stdout streams in order to determine Kind, right? So it's not a simple case of splitting the output handler from the logic that invokes the compiler?

commits.message:
fix support for showWarnings option in eclipse compiler

Previous implementation of turning off warnings was trying to achieve this
by enabling OPTION_SuppressWarnings, but it was wrong. Enabling this
option tell eclipse to honor @SuppressWarning annotations only, and does
not turn off all other warnings.

To do this we have to iterate thru all the options, and change those that
were set as WARNING to IGNORE. This is how the do it for example in
eclipse batch compiler.
Remove stray println that shouldn't have been committed.
Add missing copyright and some notes to clarify the pull request

Different approach for error-prone compiler plugin: refactor plexus-compiler-javac to allow easier extension and classloading, and depend directly on error_prone_core from plexus-compiler-javac-errorprone.
Add an error-prone compiler to plexus-compilers, so error-prone can be easily used by Maven projects.

issue_comments.body: Oh, I checked in the example user of the plugin with some updates also; see https://code.google.com/p/error-prone/source/browse/examples/maven/pom.xml

- deprecated some constructors in CompilerMessage which doesn't use the new Kind enum
- plexus-compiler-javac should now fully use the CompilerResult object to encapsulate the compilation success result

issue_comments.body: Have you tried tycho-compiler-jdt? It uses more recent JDT compiler and I am pretty sure does generate .class files compatible with eclipse debugger (did not check other IDEs)
thanks for accepting ... a reference to my name in SCM history would be nice ;-)  are there any plans for releasing 1.8.3 soon?

Yeah it requires running on 1.6.  Since 1.6 includes bug fixes not found in 1.5, and you can build for 1.5 (and earlier) on 1.6, and the year is 2012, I don't feel bad about requiring people to do it this way.  And if they really must run on 1.5 they can always downgrade the compiler plugin version...

In the long run it'd be nice to use the javax.tools API in forked mode as well, perhaps using a socket for IPC to properly send in options and categorize the output.
I didn't change the behavior of forked mode at all - it still uses the old crappy output parser.

Yeah basically to do it "right" you'd want to have a Java process which starts up a main class from plexus-compiler-javac which establishes a socket back to the main process, and uses that to send diagnostics (encoded with their proper type, line numbers, etc) that can be sent/received right in object form, instead of exec'ing javac and trying to heuristically parse it (which _is_ possible, just much more difficult).
This would be accompanied by something like this: http://github.com/dmlloyd/maven-plugins/commit/570453e which allows the compiler plugin to support the new diagnostic Kind enum.

The reason I avoided it is twofold: first, the API change applies (or can apply) to other languages so the dependency there seemed a bit odd.  The second reason is that by having it here, it is still _possible_ to run on Java 5 (if you stick with forked mode).  Both of these reasons are pretty thin though, so if they're not compelling enough I'm happy to use `Diagnostic.Kind` instead.
Updated accordingly.
Updated one more time to make sure the formatting matches (the Oracle JDK likes to copy the file name into the message, causing it to appear twice; I just remove it if it is already in the string).
FYI this seems to not be working.  Annotation processors are reporting everything as WARNING even if they're emitted at NOTE or OTHER.
@dmlloyd: if you can be sure that the forked compiler is in fact javac, you can use `-XDrawDiagnostics` to make the output much easier and safer to parse.
My guess is that a `JavaCompiler` as a singleton is thread-safe and it is the `CompilationTask` which is not.

review_comments.body: Why not just use `javax.tools.Diagnostic.Kind` to begin with? You introduce a Java 6 dependency in `plexus-compiler-api` but since you are doing so already in `plexus-compiler-javac` this seems harmless.
Check for `null` here and emit a polite message suggesting that the user might be accidentally running on a JRE rather than a JDK.

issue_comments.body: I have fixed the key issue if you have the time to review
I do not use plexus-compiler anymore myself so it's not likely I will look at it.
Other Maven committers generally keep up though.

If you're using the eclipse compiler you may actually want to look at the Takari Lifecycle which has modern support for JDT including proper access restriction and proper incremental compilation.

http://takari.io/book/40-lifecycle.html
Will move pull request to codehaus-plexus/plexus-compiler.
I'll re-open on codehaus-plexus.

@md-5 No, the ownership of this plugin has moved to https://github.com/codehaus-plexus/plexus-compiler
We haven't supported this plugin directly for quite some time.
